channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Negotiators Agree to Extend Iran Nuclear Talks, Diplomats Say
item.description: Iran, the United States and five other countries agreed to a four-month extension as they try to bridge a divide over whether Iran must dismantle parts of its nuclear program, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Opinion: The Independence Referendum Is a Test of Scotland’s Confidence
item.description: Whether or not Scots opt for independence in September, the referendum will have changed perceptions of what’s possible.
item.dc:creator: By NEAL ASCHERSON
item.media:description: The Union Jack flag waved near Stirling Castle on February 3, 2014 in Stirling, Scotland.

item.title: Prosecutors Identify Bomber in 2012 Bulgaria Bus Attack
item.description: The authorities said a French-Lebanese man was part of a group responsible for the blast, which killed 7 people, including 5 Israeli tourists.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and GEORGI KANTCHEV
item.media:description: The tour bus that was destroyed by a bomb in July 2012 at Bourgas Airport in Bulgaria.

item.title: Hamas Tunnels Prompted Invasion of Gaza
item.description: Gaza militants have long used tunnels to attack Israel. A recent incursion led to the discovery of dozens, the Israeli military said.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Court Overturns Conviction of Berlusconi in Sex Case
item.description: An appeals court acquitted the former Italian prime minister of paying for sex with a minor and revoked his seven-year sentence and ban from public office.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: The former Italian prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, on Friday.

item.title: Obama Points to Pro-Russia Separatists in Downing of Malaysia Airlines Plane
item.description: The president vowed to investigate what led to the plane crash in eastern Ukraine and the loss of 298 lives.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR, SOMINI SENGUPTA and SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: Netanyahu Warns of Wider Israel Operation in Gaza
item.description: The Israeli prime minister said the ground assault could expand “significantly,” as at least 20 Palestinians were said to have been killed, and one Israeli soldier.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and FARES AKRAM
item.media:description: People left their homes Friday after Israeli tanks rolled into the northern Gaza Strip on Thursday night.

item.title: Russia Lays Blame for Malaysia Airlines Crash on Ukraine
item.description: The Kremlin rejected accusations that Russia played a role in the downing of the civilian jetliner near its border with eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Alexei Druzhinin/RIA Novosti Kremlin Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin, right, speaks to Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev after a moment of silence for those killed in the Malaysia Airlines plane crash.

item.title: World Leaders Match Anger With Calls for Inquiry Into Ukraine Plane Crash
item.description: The downing of the Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 was seen as adding impetus to calls for tighter sanctions against Russia over its role in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL, JAMES KANTER and DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China to Tighten Oversight of Internet TV Programming
item.description: China’s top broadcast regulator has instructed Internet TV providers to remove any programming they are not authorized to broadcast, in what analysts see as the latest step for greater control of online media.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: The Internet has greatly expanded the number of television programs that can be seen in China, including American series such as "The Big Bang Theory."

item.title: Israeli Military Invades Gaza, With Sights Set on Hamas Operations
item.description: Israel said it would target tunnels that could infiltrate its territory after cease-fire talks failed to de-escalate the air war that had raged for 10 days.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers near the Gaza Strip on Thursday. Israel’s assault came in answer to an attack by militants through a tunnel.

item.title: Cleaning Up Varanasi Is a Test for Narendra Modi
item.description: The new prime minister has promised to tackle Varanasi’s many problems and to turn the downtrodden city into a showcase of culture and small business.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHANIE STROM

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: All Aboard the (Officially Renamed) Grand Rivers and Mountains Train
item.description: China’s bullet trains are undergoing a commercial rechristening now that train operators are responsible for their own profits, according to a Shanghai newspaper.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: A Hexie Hao (Harmony) bullet train in Shenyang, China. The once uniformly named trains are starting to be rechristened for commercial sponsors.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Britain Urged to Live Up to Responsibilities in Hong Kong
item.description: Two of Hong Kong’s most prominent democracy activists, Anson Chan and Martin Lee, raised their concerns about Chinese rule before a British parliamentary committee this week.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Martin Lee, right, a founder of the Democracy Party, who spoke before a British parliamentary committee this week, joined Cardinal Joseph Zen, center, the former head of the Roman Catholic Church in Hong Kong, and others in a walk for universal suffrage on June 14.

item.title: U.S. Officials Say They Suspect SA-11 or SA-20 Missiles Brought Down Malaysia Jet
item.description: Early in the inquiry into the downing of Malaysia Airlines 17 in Ukraine, determining accountability was impossible, in part because three forces in or near the area could possess SA-11s.
item.dc:creator: By C.J. CHIVERS

item.title: Jetliner Explodes Over Ukraine; Struck by Missile, Officials Say
item.description: Malaysia Airlines 17, which was carrying 298 people onboard, was shot down by a surface-to-air missile that might have been Russian made, American officials said.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE, ERIC SCHMITT and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: The fiery crash left debris strewn across several square miles in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine, near the Russian border.

item.title: Earlier Downing of Transport Plane Over Ukraine Foreshadowed Tragedy
item.description: Three days before the downing of a Malaysian civilian airliner, a Ukrainian transport plane was shot down by a surface-to-air missile while flying at 21,000 feet.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, MARK MAZZETTI and C.J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: A woman at Kuala Lumpur International Airport reacted to the news that a Malaysia Airlines plane had crashed in Ukraine.

item.title: Tragedy on Top of Crisis May Strengthen Stand Against Russia in U.S. and Europe
item.description: If the Malaysia Airlines jet was downed by pro-Russian separatists, it will reinforce the United States’ urging for a stronger stance against Moscow.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: A girl placed flowers at the Netherlands Embassy in Kiev, Ukraine, on Thursday after the crash of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, which was en route from Amsterdam.

item.title: World Briefing: Tunisia: Militants Hit Soldiers in Deadly Attack
item.description: An extremist group believed linked to Al Qaeda’s North Africa arm claimed responsibility for the attack that killed at least 14 soldiers, the authorities said Thursday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Ex-Lawmaker Charged in Child Pornography Case
item.description: Sebastian Edathy has been charged with possessing pornographic photos and videos of children.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Malaysia Airlines Plane Leaves Trail of Debris
item.description: Local residents and rescue workers saw smoldering debris litter miles of sparsely populated Ukrainian farmland after Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crashed.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: American Spy Chief Leaves
item.description: The United States’ top spy in Germany has left the country, the American Embassy in Berlin said Thursday, a week after Germany demanded that the C.I.A.’s Berlin station chief leave.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Air Disaster Strains Moscow’s Competing Strategy on Ukrainian Rebels
item.description: The Kremlin’s double game in Ukraine — publicly endorsing peace talks while secretly supporting the separatists — appeared less crafty than disastrous after the downing of a Malaysian jet.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Fraud Case Against Senator
item.description: The police have charged Mike Duffy, a suspended Conservative senator who was once a close ally of Prime Minister Stephen Harper, with 31 counts of fraud, breach of trust and bribery.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Egypt Cuts Tax Breaks for Fuel; Few Protest
item.description: Critics say that President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi call for a drastic cut to energy subsidies in order to decrease the country’s budget deficit will harm vulnerable citizens.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: “Work hard and bear with me,” President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi told Egyptians.
